results.headline: Review: In Kevin Smith’s ‘Yoga Hosers,’ Enlightenment Is Elusive
results.summary_short: This film, the second in a comedy-horror trilogy, features a quirky Johnny Depp and two heroines named Colleen.

results.headline: Review: Jokes, Not Punches, Land With a Thud in ‘Skiptrace’

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kickboxer: Vengeance,’ Duty Calls for an Unpracticed Fighter
results.summary_short: In John Stockwell’s film, a man seeking to avenge his slain brother trains under a martial-arts master. Guess who: Jean-Claude Van Damme.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Morgan,’ a Snow White With Lips Stained Red
results.summary_short: This film, directed by Luke Scott (whose father is Ridley Scott), focuses on a girl who is pale and fast, strong and hungry.

results.display_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger
results.headline: Review: ‘The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger’ Lauds a Renaissance Man
results.summary_short: These four film shorts, each by a different director, evoke aspects of a brilliant art historian and essayist living in the French Alps.

results.headline: Review: Jason Statham in ‘Mechanic: Resurrection,’ a Hit Man on Cruise Control
results.summary_short: The latest foray for the Mechanic takes him around the world after his nemesis arranges a triple assassination he can’t refuse.

results.headline: ‘Mia Madre’ Review: Mom’s in the Hospital. The Riot Scene Needs Retakes.
results.summary_short: Nanni Moretti’s film, starring Margherita Buy as a movie director and John Turturro as an American star, makes a case for blurriness in art and life.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Fatima,’ a Muslim Mother Working in France Hits Her Limit
results.summary_short: This film by Philippe Faucon, based on two books by Fatima Elayoubi, depicts tensions between a North African immigrant in Lyon and her teenage daughter.

results.headline: Review: ‘In Order of Disappearance’ Emits a Dash of ‘Fargo’

results.headline: Review: ‘Hands of Stone’ Returns Robert De Niro to the Ring but Pulls Its Punches
results.summary_short: Jonathan Jakubowicz’s film has scattered pleasures, like Mr. De Niro’s performance as Roberto Durán’s trainer. But the boxing scenes do not come within swinging distance of “Raging Bull.”

results.headline: Review: In ‘Blood Father,’ Mel Gibson Plays With Pulp Fiction
results.summary_short: The movie, directed by Jean-François Richet, finds the grizzled loner of a hero fighting to protect his daughter.

results.headline: Review: ‘Don’t Breathe’: Whose Bright Idea Was It to Rob a Blind Man?
results.summary_short: With solid suspense, murky lighting and “gotcha!” scares, Fede Alvarez’s film will probably please fans intrigued by those elements.

results.headline: Review: Rachel Weisz Toys With Identity in ‘Complete Unknown’
results.summary_short: In Joshua Marston’s film, a man with a shaky marriage meets an unnerving old flame who has lived under a series of assumed personas.

results.headline: Review: ‘Dying to Know’ How to Turn on, Tune in, Drop Out
results.summary_short: A documentary charts the relationship between Timothy Leary and Ram Dass, and their takes on expanded consciousness.

results.headline: Review: ‘Floyd Norman: An Animated Life’: He Broke Barriers at Disney
results.summary_short: Mr. Norman, the first African-American animator on Disney’s staff, hand-drew scenes for classics including “The Jungle Book” and “Sleeping Beauty.”

results.headline: Review: ‘The Hollars’: Domestic Meltdowns in Middle America
results.summary_short: John Krasinski directs and stars in a story of a man who finds that although he can go home again, the place remains a mess.

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Intervention,’ There’s a Big Chill in the Air

results.headline: Review: Pondering All of Life’s ‘What Ifs’ in ‘Is That You?’
